content: Farming is what built this area but it's getting harder every year. Input costs are insane - fertilizer, diesel, everything. Peanut prices don't keep up. I'm the third generation on this land and I worry about passing it on.
participant_profile: M, 58, Peanut farmer, Lee County, Black, third-generation farmer, land ownership important
section: Opening: Life in Rural Southwest Georgia
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you for being here. Tell me about life in this part of Georgia.

content: I work at Phoebe Putney - it's the only hospital for miles. We're understaffed, overwhelmed. If people here need specialized care, they drive to Macon or Atlanta. That's two hours. People die in that gap.
participant_profile: F, 44, Hospital nurse, Albany, Black, sole regional hospital, healthcare access worried
section: Opening: Life in Rural Southwest Georgia
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you for being here. Tell me about life in this part of Georgia.

content: I have a college degree and I manage a Dollar General. That's the economy here. Dollar stores and fast food. No career jobs. Young people leave as soon as they can.
participant_profile: F, 35, Dollar General manager, Dawson, Black, underemployed despite degree
section: Opening: Life in Rural Southwest Georgia
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you for being here. Tell me about life in this part of Georgia.

content: Fuel costs hit us hard down here. Everything is far apart. I drive for a living and I'm barely making it. $5 diesel was killing me.
participant_profile: M, 48, Truck driver, Albany, Black, long-haul routes, fuel costs crushing
section: Opening: Life in Rural Southwest Georgia
